title: 2016 Lecture 02 Maps of Meaning: Playable and non-playable games
description:
People need information about how to act, as well as information about what the world is made of. These two forms of information are neither delivered nor created in the same manner. Information about how to act is moral information. It is useful to use the idea of "game" to understand the structure of moral information.

So let me know.

We’re going to start with a proposition,
and the proposition is that in order to orient

One class of information is information about
the nature of the objective world, and the

That’s the technology.

The philosophical technology that's behind
the Scientific Revolution - involves stripping

of certain kinds of actions because when you

lay out an experiment, you're not just talking
about what happened, you're talking about
what you did and then what happened.

And you're supposed to be able to do it in
a way that ensures that if someone else followed

the exact same procedure, they would obviously
observe the same consequences.

And, in some sense, we’re trying to establish

That's one way of thinking about it, and obviously

Whether or not it works in a Darwinian sense,

But it doesn't really matter at the moment

Now, people think the world is an objective

It’s partly debatable because it's actually

So what that means in a way is no matter what
you know about anything, you don't know everything

And so, you kind of ground out in ignorance

So what means is you that you have to buttress

One of those sets of assumptions is usually
